facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 311 to 366 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 311 to 366 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and decrees dated December 6, 1957, December 16, 1958, January 29, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decrees dated December 6, 1957, December 16, 1958, January 29, 1959 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 343 and 381-416 of 1955, 548 of 1958 49-55 and 57-67 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: On October 29, 1941, the Hardwar Union Municipal Board issued notification No. 4188/XI-416-41 imposing a toll on motor vehicles and tongas entering or leaving the municipal limits with passengers at 2 annas per passenger.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1941, the Hardwar Union Municipal Board  for brevity called the Board in this Judgment  issued a numberification  No. 4188/XI-416-41  by which it imposed a toll on motor vehicles and tongas entering or leaving the municipal limits with passengers, at the rate of 2 annas per passenger.

facts.text: Notification of 1941 exempted persons travelling in motor vehicles and tongas from Rishikesh.

anchor.surface_text: There were nine classes of persons who were exempted and one such class was persons travelling in motor vehicles and tongas from Rishikesh.

facts.text: Notification of 1941 was issued under Section 128(1)(xiv) of the U.P. Municipalities Act 1916.

anchor.surface_text: Exemption certificates valid to the end of the calendar year were available in respect of some of the other classes. The numberification purported to be issued in exercise of powers companyferred by S. 128 1  xiv  of the U.P. Municipalities Act 1916  U.P. Act 2 of 1916 .

facts.text: On February 22, 1955, the Board issued notification No. 830/XXIII-16 C -53-54 increasing toll to 4 annas per passenger and adding rickshaws.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1955, a second numberification was issued  No. 830/XXIII-16 C -53-54 , this time in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 128 1  vii  of the Act, and it increased the toll from 2 annas to 4 annas per passenger and added rickshaws to the vehicles.

facts.text: Second notification removed exemption for persons travelling from Rishikesh.

anchor.surface_text: This numberification also removed the exemption in favour of persons travelling from Rishikesh.

facts.text: Second notification issued under Section 128(1)(vii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: this time in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 128 1  vii  of the Act,

facts.text: Board established toll-barrier on Rishikesh-Hardwar road at Kharkhari within Hardwar Municipality limits.

anchor.surface_text: The Board established a toll-barrier on the Rishikesh Hardwar road at a place called Kharkhari within the limits of Hardwar Municipality.

facts.text: Toll collected at 4 annas per passenger from vehicles entering or departing municipal area by motor car, tonga or rickshaw.

anchor.surface_text: Toll was companylected at that barrier from vehicles entering the municipal area or departing from it, at the rate of 4 annas per passenger travelling by motor car, tonga or rickshaw.

facts.text: On September 18, 1957, third notification No. 2706B- a XI-C-57 issued amending 1941 notification and deleting Rishikesh exemption.

anchor.surface_text: On September 18, 1957, a third numberification  No. 2706B- a XI-C-57  was issued, once again in exercise of powers companyferred by s. 128 1  xiv  and the Board amended the description of the toll in the numberification of 1941 and deleted the exemption which had been granted to persons travelling between Rishikesh and Hardwar.

facts.text: Respondents are owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar.

anchor.surface_text: The last numberification was issued after the respondents who are owners of motor vehicles plying between Rishikesh and Hardwar had filed their petitions

facts.text: Respondents filed petitions under Article 226 challenging the toll before third notification.

anchor.surface_text: had filed their petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the toll.

facts.text: Mehrotra J. on September 26, 1955 held no toll on vehicles leaving municipal limits and issued writ to desist collection on leaving; upheld on entry.

anchor.surface_text: The special appeal was filed against a judgment of Mehrotra J. dated September 26, 1955. Mr. Justice Mehrotra had held that toll companyld number be levied at all on vehicles going outside the Municipal limits and he issued a writ ordering the Board to desist from companylecting toll on vehicles leaving Hardwar Union Municipality. He upheld the levy of toll on vehicles entering the municipal limits.

facts.text: Divisional Bench (Mootham J. and Shrivastava J.) on December 6, 1957 upheld toll on leaving but not if paid on entry.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment, which is impugned here by the Board as appellant, is by a Divisional Bench companysisting of Mootham J. and Shrivastava J. in a special appeal decided on December 6, 1957. ... The Divisional Bench maintained the order but held that although toll companyld be levied on vehicles leaving the municipal area, it companyld number be levied on the same vehicle if it had been once levied on its entry into the municipal area.

facts.text: Divisional Bench modified order to not levy toll on vehicles leaving after paying on entry.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench modified the order by adding a direction that the appellant Board should number levy toll on vehicles leaving the municipal limits, which had paid toll on entry into these limits.

facts.text: Divisional Bench dismissed other special appeals and certified fit for Supreme Court appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Following its own decision the Divisional Bench dismissed the other special appeals but certified all cases as fit for appeal to this Court

facts.text: Board is appellant in these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: which is impugned here by the Board as appellant,

facts.text: Section 128(1)(vii) of U.P. Municipalities Act allows toll on vehicles and other conveyances entering the municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Section 128 1  of the Act read in 1941 as follows - Taxes which may be imposed Subject to any general rules or special orders of the Provincial Government in this behalf, the taxes which a board may impose in the whole or any part of a municipality are- . . . . . . . . . . . . . . a toll on vehicles and other companyveyances, animals and laden companylies entering the municipality . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

facts.text: Tolls first imposed in Hardwar in 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Since tolls were first imposed in Hardwar in 1941,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds toll can only be collected from vehicles entering municipal limits under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: toll as such can only be companylected under the Municipalities Act from vehicles entering the municipal limits.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses appeals without modification.

anchor.surface_text: As, however, the owners of vehicles have number appealed or objected, we will only dismiss the appeals and order numbermodification in the order of the Divisional Bench.

facts.text: Appellant Board to bear costs of appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Board shall bear the cases of this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been ruled on many an occasion in this Court that local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute which erects them and endows them with such powers.

concepts.interpretation: Municipal boards exercise delegated legislative powers strictly within the statute; cannot exceed statutory limits.

anchor.surface_text: We were referred to dictionaries and to rulings of the English Courts in an attempt to widen the meaning of the word toll. There were many kinds of tolls and all, of course, must be taken to be comprehended by the entry relating to tolls in the Government of India Act, 1935 or the Constitution. There were for example toll-thorough and toll-traverse which were the two main subdivisions and there was toll-stallage.

concepts.interpretation: Toll is a tribute for privilege of passage; types include toll-thorough (through highways), toll-traverse (private ground), toll-stallage (market stalls); generally collected once, at entry.

issues.text: Whether the Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality under cl. (vii) of S. 128(1)?

anchor.surface_text: If the matter is confined to cl. vii it is clear that the Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality.

issues.text: Whether cl. (xiv) of S. 128(1) permits extension of power to levy toll on vehicles leaving the municipality?

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty in accepting the first notification in respect of toll on vehicles leaving the municipality which is sought to be supported under cl. xiv is this the Provincial Legislature expressly gave a limited power to levy toll on vehicles entering the municipality.

issues.text: Whether tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality as well as on vehicles entering the municipality?

anchor.surface_text: even if it may be right to say that tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality as well as on vehicles entering the municipality--a point which we do not decide.

issues.text: Whether toll can be levied on the same vehicle both on entry and on exit from the municipal limits?

anchor.surface_text: We need not concern ourselves with this problem which was placed before us by Mr. Setalvad because toll as such can only be collected under the Municipalities Act from vehicles entering the municipal limits.

issues.text: Whether the Divisional Bench's distinction allowing toll on exit only if not paid on entry is correct?

arguments.claim: Residuary clause (xiv) of S. 128(1) being enabling can bring full legislative power to levy tolls to aid restricted cl. (vii), allowing toll on vehicles leaving municipality

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad has relied upon both the clauses of S. 128 1  quoted above. He has further relied upon the concept of tolls which according to him envisages collection both on entry and departure. He has drawn particular attention to- the first and the third notifications in which cl. xiv is mentioned as the source of power and has contended that the clause being residuary and enabling can bring the full amplitude of the power of the legislature to levy tolls to the aid of cl. vii which is restricted in its operation.

arguments.claim: Local authorities like Board do not act as legislatures but as agents of State Legislature; powers strictly from statute

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been ruled on many an occasion in this Court that local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute

arguments.claim: S.128(1)(vii) limits toll to vehicles entering the municipality

anchor.surface_text: Section 128 1  of the Act read in 1941 as follows - Taxes which may be imposed ... a toll on vehicles and other conveyances, animals and laden animals entering the municipality

arguments.claim: Scheme of S.128 enumerates specific taxes; cl.(xiv) residuary equates to legislative powers but only for unenumerated taxes

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of S. 128 is that it enumerates by name certain taxes, and confers power on the Boards to levy them and then it enacts cl. xiv which is intended to confer other taxes which the Provincial (now the State) Legislature has authority to impose but which are not in the enumeration.

arguments.claim: Provincial power in 1941 from GIA entry 53 (tolls), delegated limited by cl.(vii) to entry only

anchor.surface_text: The powers of the Provincial Legislature in this context could flow from entries 52 and 53 only of the Provincial Legislative List... 53-Tolls.

arguments.claim: Cl.(xiv) cannot extend cl.(vii) power to levy on exit as Legislature expressly limited to entry

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty in accepting the first notification in respect of toll on vehicles leaving the municipality which is sought to be supported under cl. xiv is this the Provincial Legislature expressly gave a limited power to levy toll on vehicles entering the municipality.

arguments.claim: Larger residuary power cut down by necessary implication from specific cl.(vii)

anchor.surface_text: The larger power, if any, must be held to be cut down by necessary implication. To permit tolls to be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality would render ineffective that part of cl. vii which lays emphasis on vehicles entering the municipality.

arguments.claim: Tolls generally collected only once, at entry point

anchor.surface_text: The better view appears to be that they can be collected only once and at the point of entry only though for convenience, they may be collected at any one end as for example toll for crossing a bridge

arguments.claim: Whether tolls can be levied on exit as well is not decided

anchor.surface_text: even if it may be right to say that tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality as well as on vehicles entering the municipality--a point which we do not decide.

arguments.qualifiers: a point which we do not decide

holdings.text: The Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality under clause (vii) of Section 128(1).

anchor.surface_text: If the matter is confined to cl. vii it is clear that the Board could levy toll only on vehicles entering the municipality and not on vehicles leaving the municipality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of clause (vii) which expressly limits toll to 'vehicles ... entering the municipality'.

holdings.text: No extension of power to levy toll on vehicles leaving the municipality is possible under clause (xiv) of Section 128(1) due to specific limitation in clause (vii).

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty in accepting the first notification in respect of toll on vehicles leaving the municipality which is sought to be supported under cl. xiv is this the Provincial Legislature expressly gave a limited power to levy toll on vehicles entering the municipality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature delegated limited power via cl.(vii); residuary cl.(xiv) equates to legislative powers but cannot override specific enumeration; larger power cut down by implication to avoid rendering cl.(vii) ineffective.

holdings.text: The power to collect tolls under the U.P. Municipalities Act is limited to vehicles entering the municipal limits and cannot be extended to vehicles leaving.

anchor.surface_text: We need not concern ourselves with this problem which was placed before us by Mr. Setalvad because toll as such can only be collected under the Municipalities Act from vehicles entering the municipal limits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhausts delegated power from cl.(vii); unaffected by general nature of tolls or residuary clause.

holdings.text: In the Hardwar Municipality, the power to collect tolls was limited in 1941 by clause (vii) of Section 128(1) and continues to be so limited.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, sufficient to say that in the Hardwar Municipality the power to collect tolls was limited in 1941 by cl. vii of S. 128 (1) and that power continues to be so limited.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies statutory limits to facts of notifications issued under the Act from 1941 onwards.

holdings.text: The distinction made by the Divisional Bench allowing toll on exit only if not paid on entry is not correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No power to levy on exit at all under the Act; irrelevant consideration of passenger numbers.

holdings.text: The decision of Mehrotra J. holding no toll leviable on vehicles leaving the municipal limits was right.

anchor.surface_text: the decision of Mehrotra J. was right in all the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with statutory limits under cl.(vii).

holdings.text: Local authorities like municipal boards exercise delegated powers strictly within the statute and do not act as legislatures.

anchor.surface_text: Now it has been ruled on many an occasion in this Court that local authorities like the Board do not act as legislatures when they impose a tax but as the agent of the State Legislatures. Their powers and the extent of these powers must be found in the statute

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows established precedent on nature of municipal taxing power.

holdings.text: Appeals dismissed without modification as vehicle owners have not appealed or objected; appellant Board to bear costs.

anchor.surface_text: As, however, the owners of vehicles have not appealed or objected, we will only dismiss the appeals and order no modification in the order of the Divisional Bench. The appellant Board shall bear the costs of this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural disposition; no cross-appeal by respondents.

holdings.text: Whether tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving as well as entering is not decided.

anchor.surface_text: even if it may be right to say that tolls as such can be levied on vehicles leaving the municipality as well as on vehicles entering the municipality--a point which we do not decide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly left open as unnecessary to decide given statutory limits.

holdings.text: The better view is that tolls are collected only once, at the point of entry.

anchor.surface_text: The better view appears to be that they can be collected only once and at the point of entry only though for convenience, they may be collected at any one end as for example toll for crossing a bridge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical and definitional analysis of toll types; obiter as irrelevant to statutory power.

anchor.surface_text: we will only dismiss the appeals and order numbermodification in the order of the Divisional Bench. The appellant Board shall bear the cases of this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; no modification in the order of the Divisional Bench
